item.title: The Sims 4: How to Do the Motherlode Cheat
item.description:
The Sims 4 and its previous entries have many cheats that make it easier for Sims to prosper in life. There are cheats for just about anything in The Sims 4 , especially if players install mods. However, some of the game's best cheats are part of it and can be used even if players want to stick to a vanilla save file.

Fans can play this however they choose, but earning money and sustaining a household is undoubtedly one of the most important parts of The Sims 4. Various cheats can be used to increase a Sim's household funds, but none is as iconic as the motherlode cheat, which is what this guide focuses on.

How to Use Motherlode in The Sims 4

There are two things that players need to learn to do before being able to use the Motherlode cheat: opening the cheat console and enabling cheats. To enable cheats in The Sims 4 , players must open the cheat console to insert the code that activates cheating.

Players on PC can open the cheat console by pressing Ctrl + Shift+ C, but those on console must press all four trigger buttons in order to do it. Then, they must enter the code "testingcheats on" or "testingcheats true", which will immediately activate cheats.

Lastly, still using the cheat console, players have to input the code "motherlode", and 50,000 Simoleons will be added to their household funds.

How to Disable Cheats in The Sims 4

If players don't want to use any more cheats other than Motherlode and would like to go back to a cheat-free game, then they can reopen the cheat console and enter the code "testingcheats off" or "testingcheats false".

Once done, no other cheat menus will appear while gamers are playing The Sims 4 - unless they enable them once again in the future.

item.title: The First Berserker: Khazan - How To Beat Maluca
item.description:
Maluca , the leader of the Knivesveil , was once a loyal soldier of the empire working for the emperor. However, his greed for power strayed him from the path, and now he is a troublesome foe in the way of Khazan . Maluca is the second boss in the game that significantly raises the difficulty, requiring precise Brink Guards and dodges to prevent players from losing half their health bar in a single mistake.

The boss is located right after the Throne of the Veil ( Blade Nexus ) during the seventh mission inside Nadin Quarry. Letâ€™s go over all of his attacks and the best strategies to defeat him in The First Berserker: Khazan .

Maluca Attack Overview In The First Berserker: Khazan

Attack

Image

How To Avoid

Phase 1

Double Thrust

Maluca thrusts his greatswords, then follows up with two wide swings. Guarding or dodging both work here .

Charged Gale

The boss charges his greatsword and releases a gust of air three times, with the third release being stronger. You need to time your Brink Guard or dodge when the weapon flashes , signaling an incoming gust.

Spinning Burst

Maluca spins around, performing a Burst Attack. Counterattack right before he makes contact .

Descending Slam

The boss jumps up, spins in the air, and then slams to the ground. In the second phase, he can perform this twice. Time your guard to avoid taking damage.

Glowing Impact

Maluca charges his greatswords until they start shining, then slams the ground. Dodge right after you see the shine .

Phase 2

Greatsword Slam

Immediately, as the second phase starts, the boss jumps up and slams the ground, then begins to charge and vibrate the area, causing an eruption. Brink Guard the slam, then run out of the area or dodge as the eruption takes place.

Deadly Shethe

After the slam attack, Maluca takes out his curved sword, sheathes it, and attempts a quick-draw attack. This attack has an audio cue and must be dodged ; otherwise, it deals significant damage and causes Chaos buildup.

10-Hit Curved Combo

The boss strikes once, sheathes his sword, then jumps back to slice the ground before pushing forward with nine consecutive attacks. Brink Guarding all of these significantly reduces the boss's stamina bar .

Leaping Grab

Maluca leaps into the air before thrusting his sword at the player. This cannot be blocked, so dodging is your only option when you hear the audio cue .

Quickdraw

The boss sheathes his sword before performing a quick-draw attack that inflicts Chaos buildup. Dodging is an option, but Brink Guard is highly recommended as it will stagger him . He can sometimes alter the attack by rolling twice before drawing the weapon.

Arc Slashes

The boss performs three powerful wide-arc slashes while leaping into the air. Guarding against these attacks can significantly impact his stamina meter.

Double Slam

Maluca takes out his greatsword and performs two airborne slams. Guarding or dodging at the right time are both viable options. Once his health is extremely low, he can add a third slam to the sequence .

Relentless Gale

The boss charges up his greatsword and releases a powerful gust of air seven times, with each subsequent attack having a shorter charge time. You need to Brink Guard while gradually reducing the time between each guard to match the decreasing charge time .

How To Beat Maluca In The First Berserker: Khazan

Maluca starts off the fight using his greatswords. His attacks are quite slow, so it is recommended that you try to dodge most of them. Staying on the offensive against this boss is the best approach because, similar to The First Berserker Khazan 's other human bosses, Maluca's stamina bar actively increases , making it quite difficult to force him into an exhausted state. Despite this, his stamina bar goes down quickly , so dodging all of his attacks and constantly attacking him should get you two Brutal Attacks before he shifts into the second phase.

Phase 2

The second phase is where this fight truly tests your skills. Maluca starts the phase with a slam followed by a quickdraw attack, briefly slowing down the game and giving you a chance to dodge . What follows is a barrage of quick attacks, all of which you must Brink Guard to crush his stamina bar and land a free Brutal Attack.

The key attack that can shift the fight in your favor is his quickdraw. Maluca sheathes his weapon, and after a brief flash, he delivers a devastating strike . This not only deals heavy damage but also builds up Chaos, reducing your max health unless cured. Fortunately, Chaos Cleanse Potions , which you may have acquired along the way, can instantly remove this effect . Equipping Chaos Resistant Necklaces and Rings before the fight will also make this battle much more manageable.

As you chip away more of his health, Maluca will switch back to his greatswords , performing attacks similar to those in the first phase but with additional hits. His attacks become more relentless, requiring quicker reactions. One of his most dangerous moves is an attack where he unleashes consecutive gusts of air . You can Brink Guard each one right after you see the flash animation. However, with each gust, he reduces the charge time, leaving you with less time to react and forcing you to guard with near-perfect timing.

Be sure to upgrade your armor and gear at the Blacksmith before the fight or craft a set with a set bonus that will benefit you in this battle.

Rewards For Beating Maluca In The First Berserker: Khazan

Defeating the boss will earn you the following rewards

  • 8,265 Gold
  • 22,200 Lacrima
  • Choas-Ridden Armor Piece / Chaos-Ridden Greatsword
  • Shieldman's Ring / Necklace of Faith
  • Transmuation Mist
  • Choas Fragment (Fighting the boss again drops this)

item.title: No Man's Sky Releases New Relics Update
item.description:
Summary

  • Patch 5.6 (Relics Update) for No Man's Sky adds palaeontology, new features, and bug fixes.
  • Previous updates fixed launch issues and added features like companions, co-op, and base building.
  • The game remains popular due to continuous updates, making it worth playing years after release.

No Manâ€™s Sky has recently released patch 5.6, also known as the Relics Update, which adds important features like palaeontology to the popular space exploration game. This is the latest of a few substantial updates received by No Manâ€™s Sky as developer Hello Games continues to polish the experience and add more elements to the popular survival title.

Originally released in 2016, No Manâ€™s Sky suffered from a controversial launch, as many gamers were disappointed with the lack of depth in the titleâ€™s universe, as well as the prevalence of many bugs. Over the years, however, Hello Games launched many updates, fixing the gameâ€™s worst issues and adding much more content to the experience. With additional features such as the ability to find companions, play in co-op, and build bases, No Manâ€™s Sky eventually became one of the most popular space exploration games ever released.

With the new Relics Update, No Manâ€™s Sky players will be able to unearth hundreds of unique bones, assemble their fossils, and fight against gargantuan stone giants or ancient bone creatures as palaeontology is added to the game. This change adds a whole new system, as these bones will have a wide variety, and gamers will be able to sell their fossil exhibits. The patch also includes an improved Abandoned Mode, which has been streamlined and enhanced with more valuable items.

Other new features include a new skeletal companion, colossal stone effigies that can be found on planets, and much more. As usual, the 5.6 patch also fixes multiple bugs, making the experience of playing No Manâ€™s Sky smoother. Overall, the 5.6 patch is larger than some of the most recent No Manâ€™s Sky updates, which mainly fixed bugs.

The last major No Manâ€™s Sky patch was 5.5, also known as Worlds: Part 2. This huge previous update introduced greater world variety, such as water worlds and gas giants, ruined civilizations, new missions, and much more to the popular space exploration title.

With these updates, No Manâ€™s Sky is likely worth playing in 2025 even for gamers who have already tried it once. Even when considering only the updates in the last year or so, Hello Games did a good job of overhauling some of No Manâ€™s Sky's systems and greatly improving the experience. This made the game feel fresh almost a decade after its original release, and gave a mysterious universe for players to explore at their own pace.

No Man's Sky 5.6 Patch Notes (Relics Update)

Collect and Display Skeletons

  • Planetary fossil beds now contain a vast array of specific bone formations.
  • Each of these bones can be placed as a decorative base part, either individually or mounted on a display plinth.
  • Larger display plinths allow a collection of bones to be reassembled into a complete skeleton, allowing the design and reassembly of ancient and extinct beings.
  • Completed displays can be packaged into an easily transportable module, allowing them to be re-deployed in other locations, traded with other players, or sold on the galactic market.
  • A new planetary dig-site building has been added, serving as a hub for interested fossil collectors.
  • The icon for planetary fossils has been improved.
  • A small tutorial mission has been added to guide new palaeontologists.
  • A new palaeontology section has been added to the guide.

Fossil Exchange

  • A fossil collector has been added to the Space Station.
  • Surplus fossils can be exchanged with the fossil collector, allowing players to target specific skeleton components for their designs.
  • The fossil collector will barter for items in their collection, allowing individual inventory items to be swapped.

Relics Expeditions

  • Expedition Eighteen, Relics, will begin shortly and run for approximately six weeks.
  • Rewards include new posters, decals and titles; a living stone suit customisation set; the unique Basilisk Crown staff; a mysterious skeletal companion; and the exclusive Living Stone jetpack.

Stone Guardians

  • Fossil beds are now watched over by a vigilant stone eye, ready to protect the bones from those who would exhume them.
  • Disturbing the vigilant eye may yield valuable rewards, but comes at the cost of awakening the guardians.
  • Two forms of stone guardian await - a huge living statue, and a whirling storm of re-animated rock.
  • Huge guardian statues have been added to relic worlds.

Skeletal Lifeforms

  • A new and highly rare skeletal lifeform has been added to some planets.
  • Some planets are now home to the elusive titanic bone-wormâ€¦

Quality of Life and UI

  • Planets in your current system can now be marked from the discovery page, adding a marker to the starship navigation systems.
  • Added an accessibility option to increase the contrast in mission-critical UI panels.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause the camera to move erratically back and forth while inside high-ceilinged rooms in player bases.
  • Nearby NPCs that have specific unseen interactions will now be highlighted with a marker.
  • Added a new water state for ocean worlds with significantly larger waves.
  • Various volumetric and other atmospheric effects no longer play on planets without an atmosphere.
  • Story details from the In Stellar Multitudes mission now appear in the Journey Records page in the catalogue.
  • Reduced the number of corrupt drones that attack player settlements.
  • The space station marker is now dynamically offset, preventing the marker from obscuring the station while at a distance.
  • Fixed a number of minor text issues in some extractor UIs.
  • Fixed a number of minor text and icon issues in shop interactions.
  • Fixed an issue that caused companions that were set to use no accessories to have a random accessory assigned after re-summoning them.
  • Fixed an issue that caused the starship to too-aggressively lock on to markers when engaging the pulse engine.
  • An organic version of the Teleport Receiver has been added for use in living starships.
  • Fixed an issue that caused the repair requirements for several living starship technologies to all be the same.
  • Lingering on-screen display messages that report pulse drive errors will now clear as soon as a successful pulse drive engagement is detected.

Save System

  • Significantly improved the compression used for saved games, improving filesizes and upload/download times for players in the cross-save beta.
  • Created a section for cross-save settings within the general Options menu.
  • Players in the cross-save beta are now alerted to situations where uploads are timing out, and can manually adjust how long the game will wait for a successful upload before detecting a timeout and cancelling.

Cooking

  • New fossil-related cooking recipes have been added.
  • Base storage container inventories are now accessible while cooking.
  • Fixed an issue that prevented access to the nutrient processorâ€™s internal storage while on a freighter or the Exo-Skiff.
  • Fixed a number of issues while cooking the Exo-Skiff, including progress resetting or incorrect items appearing in various slots.
  • Cronosâ€™ grill on the Space Anomaly can now be used by several players at once.
  • Fixed an issue that made it impossible to cook jellied eels.

Abandoned Mode Improvements

  • Multi-Tools found in abandoned mode are now always free, but start with damaged slots.
  • Settlement-related missions will no longer start in abandoned mode.
  • Abandoned space stations now have access to Exosuit, starship, and Multi-Tool upgrade stations.
  • Additional salvage boxes have been added around abandoned space stations containing valuable upgrades and inventory expansion modules.
  • Purple systems are now unlocked automatically in abandoned mode.
  • In abandoned mode, crashed freighter containers and other buried caches can now contain additional valuable upgrades.

Optimization

  • Introduced a number of optimisations to planetary prop rendering.
  • Introduced an optimisation to dynamic physics groups.
  • Introduced a significant memory optimisation for nav mesh generation.
  • Introduced a number of minor texture memory optimisations.
  • Introduced an optimisation for loading large bases.
  • Introduced a number of optimisations for text display, particularly in the Journey Records pages.
  • Introduced an optimisation to the various catalogue and guide pages.

Other Bug Fixes

  • Fixed a number of issues that could occur when warping on board another playerâ€™s freighter.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause water creatures to be generated for a planet that would never have deep enough water for those creatures to spawn.
  • Fixed a number of mission blockers in They Who Returned.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause some bases to become invisible when constructed at the waterâ€™s surface on ocean planets.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause PC players to appear jerky in cross-platform multiplayer.
  • Fixed a rare issue that could cause playersâ€™ settings to reset in VR.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause NPCs to sink into the floor.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause a softlock when browsing the Exocraft inventory.
  • Fixed a rare hang on load when returning to a savegame that was saved while in an Exocraft after playing in multiplayer.
  • Fixed a rare crash related to camera shakes.
  • Fixed a memory-related crash on PlayStation 5.
  • Fixed a number of rare crashes related to mesh scaling.
  • Fixed a number of rare maths-related crashes.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause some planetary props to pop in.
  • Fixed a number of Mac-specific rendering issues.
  • Fixed a rare issue that could cause saves to reach a max size and stop saving on Nintendo Switch - saves can now expand as required.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause multiple ships to become docked to the same landing pad.
  • Improved the placement positioning of decorative base building props.
  • Fixed a number of text clipping issues in large popups.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause a teleport destination to have two copies of a mission marker added.
  • Fixed an issue that could make interactions difficult on freighters that were summoned a long way from the centre of the solar system.
  • Fixed a number of issues affecting markers and planet labels when entering atmosphere.
  • Fixed a rare issue that could cause empty systems to generate incorrect information about their potential Atlas Stations.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause the galaxy map to incorrectly choose a purple system as part of its path to a distant star when purple systems are not unlocked.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause players to start in a purple system when arriving in a new galaxy, when purple systems were not unlocked.
  • Fixed an issue that caused the water effects from the Nautilon submarine to remain in the world after summoning the sub to a new location.
  • Fixed an issue that prevented Exocraft laser effects from playing correctly in multiplayer.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause erratic torso movements in Sentinel mechs.
  • Fixed an issue that could cause the ship to hover as if above water when reloading on a planet.
  • Fixed a number of inconsistencies in creature descriptions, where creatures would be described as being from the wrong environment.
  • Fixed an incorrect texture being used for the Titan expedition in the expedition history screen.
  • Fixed a number of decals and posters from previous expeditions being missing from the catalogue.
  • Fixed an issue that caused a number of unusable and legacy items to be included in the catalogue.
